comments:
See bug 80670, same symptoms.  It was resolved for Windows but still exists in linux amd64 eclipse 3.2.

Again, same error message and scenario as 80670 - "Error validating location "". Keep location anyway?"
Is there anything in the Error log?

I cannot reproduce the error because when I open the cvs repositories window, now I get a message saying this:
"Unable to create view: Plug-in org.eclipse.team.cvs.ui was unable to load class org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ui.repo.RepositoriesView."

I do not have an error log from this bug's error.  I tried deleting the eclipse folder and my workspace folder and the .eclipse folder and re-extracting eclipse, but I still get this new error message.

What VM are you using?

I've had the same results with the two VMs I've tried:

java version "1.5.0_08"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_08-b03)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 1.5.0_08-b03, mixed mode)

AND

java version "1.4.2"
gij (GNU libgcj) version 4.1.0 (Ubuntu 4.1.0-1ubuntu8)
The inability to load classes looks like a runtime issue. Moving to Platform/Runtime to see if they can throw any light on the situation.

(In reply to comment #5)
> The inability to load classes looks like a runtime issue. Moving to
> Platform/Runtime to see if they can throw any light on the situation.
> 

I was able to reproduce the "Error validating location "". Keep location anyway?" bug on a different system with an identical software setup and I have confirmed that there was no error log generated.  

Note: there are two bugs being referenced in this report now, the second one being the runtime class loading one.  I do not know if the two are related or not.

I'll move this back to CVS since the original problem is the validation error. If you are still experiencing the class load failure, I would suggest you log another bug since it is different enough from the validation error to make it impossible to track the two problems in a single bug.
To get back to the original problem, are you able to reproduce the problem? If so, is there any errors in the error log?
Yes I can reproduce it, and nothing shows up in the error log.  The dialog that comes up doesn't appear to be an error dialog, but rather a confirmation dialog.
Could you give the set of steps you follwed to reproduce the problem?

Create a new Repository Location using extssh.  The location settings I use are Host:adams.cs.washington.edu, Rep. Path:/projects/db/brharris, User:brharris  You don't need to specify a PW.  Default port, and choose validate connection on finish.  Then click finish and the dialog should appear with the message stated previousily.

(In reply to comment #11)
> Create a new Repository Location using extssh.  The location settings I use are
> Host:adams.cs.washington.edu, Rep. Path:/projects/db/brharris, User:brharris 
> You don't need to specify a PW.  Default port, and choose validate connection
> on finish.  Then click finish and the dialog should appear with the message
> stated previousily.

It is the trivial reason.  You have not given the correct password.
This happens when I supply a password too, I just didn't want to post it.

I tried what you suggested and I just get prompted for the password when I provide an invalid password. Is it possible that you have a firewall program running on yur PC that is intercepting the connection and causing it to fail?
Unless there is a firewall included and enabled in a basic ubuntu 6.06 install, no.  I am behind a router, but this problem doesn't occur in windows behind the same router.

Created an attachment (id=48311)
Screenshot from Ubuntu 6.06

Brian - here's a screenshot of my Ubuntu 6.06 machine (default install). Notice I get prompted for a password. I'm running the Sun 1.4.2_12 jvm on the Eclipse 3.2 release (although I also tried it out on 3.3 M1 with the same results).

To make sure we're on the same page, can you try a fresh 3.2 install using the Sun 1.4.2 jvm? If it still doesn't work can you try it on another linux box? Let me know how it goes.
I am on an amd64 machine, are you?  If so, please link to a 1.4.2_12 download for amd64.  Thanks.

No, I'm on an Intel 32. But you can get the jvm for amd64 here: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/download.html

Give it a try... BTW, Can you reproduce your bug on a non-amd64 Linux box?

I was asking for a link because I didn't see an amd64 version there, could you supply a direct link?

I only have an amd64 machine.

Hmm, it looks like there are no amd64 releases for 1.4.2. The other thing you can try is running a network analyzer (I tried Ethereal which comes with Ubuntu) to see if you're actually reaching the server. At our end, we don't have any amd64 machines available so our options for further investigation are limited...

The prompt for password has appeared, so I guess that TCP connection has
been established successfully.

How about trying ssh command on xterm?

  $ ssh -v -v -v brharis@adams.cs.washington.edu

Can you successfully login from your amd64 linux box
with your valid password?
Yes.

(In reply to comment #22)
> Yes.

How about log messages from following command?

  $ ssh -v -v -v brharis@adams.cs.washington.edu
Brian, your last communication to me indicated that you were trying to track this down. Please reopen if you have found anything that may help us out.

Our usual practice is to move bugs to the RESOLVED REMIND state when there is not enough information provided to address the reported issue and more information has been requested. This bug has been in the RESOLVED REMIND state for quite some time so it is being CLOSED. If you can provide the requested information or you otherwise feel that this is still an issue, please reopen the bug. If you are unable to open it due to a lack or permissions, please add a comment to the bug stating that you would like to have the request reconsidered.  I applogize for this blanket approach to bug screening but there are just to many bugs in the REMIND state for us to effectively triage them. Your help in this matter is appreciated.
